title: Man and teenage boy injured in two separate stabbings at Tube stations
text:
Woodford Tube Station was forced to close this evening because of a stabbing

(Picture: BTP)

Two underground stations were forced to close because of stabbing incidents.

Trains were not stopping at Woodford station, in north-east London, while emergency services dealt with a victim at around 5.30pm.

The man was taken to hospital and treated for a back injury.

A spokesman for the British Transport Police (BTP) said: ‘A man suffered an injury to his back and has been taken to hospital for treatment.

‘Officers remain at the scene and inquiries are ongoing.’

A man was taken to hospital after being found with injuries (Picture: laurence26898)

London Underground’s Central Line confirmed the station had been closed, adding: ‘Woodford: at the moment trains are not stopping at the station. This is while police respond to an incident.

‘We’ll let you all know when the station re-opens and trains are stopping normally.’

Woodford station, which is in zone 4, was later re-opened.

This afternoon at around 3.45pm a teenage boy was also stabbed at Upney Underground station, in east London, following a fight.

The station was also closed while emergency services attended the scene.

Police said in a statement: ‘Police were called to Upney Underground Station at 15.46hrs on Monday, 7 October to reports of an altercation.

‘Officers attended. Two teenage boys were found injured. Both boys were treated at the scene by paramedics before being taken to hospital. One of them is being treated for stab injuries.

‘There have been no arrests. A crime scene is in place. Enquiries continue.’
